Review Recent advances in design of hydrogen evolution reaction electrocatalysts at high current density: A review Zhipeng Li a Xiaobin Liu a * Qingping Yu a b Xinyue Qu a Jun Wan a Zhenyu Xiao a * Jingqi Chi a Lei Wang a b * a Key Laboratory of Eco-chemical Engineering, International Science and Technology Cooperation Base of Eco-chemical Engineering and Green Manufacturing, College of Environment and Safety Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China Key Laboratory of Eco-chemical Engineering International Science and Technology Cooperation Base of Eco-chemical Engineering and Green Manufacturing College of Environment and Safety Engineering Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao Shandong 266042 China Key Laboratory of Eco-chemical Engineering, International Science and Technology Cooperation Base of Eco-chemical Engineering and Green Manufacturing, College of Environment and Safety Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China b College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao Shandong 266042 China College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China * Corresponding author. The electrolysis of water powered by renewable energy sources offers a promising method of “green hydrogen” production, which is considered to be at the heart of future carbon-neutral energy systems. In the past decades, researchers have reported a number of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalysts with activity comparable to that of commercial Pt/C, but most of them are tested within a small current density range, typically no more than 500 mA cm–2. To realize the industrial application of hydrogen production from water electrolysis, it is essential to develop high-efficiency HER electrocatalysts at high current density (HCD ≥ 500 mA cm–2). Nevertheless, it remains challenging and significant to rational design HCD electrocatalysts for HER. In this paper, the design strategy of HCD electrocatalysts is discussed, and some HCD electrocatalysts for HER are reviewed in seven categories (alloy, metal oxide, metal hydroxide, metal sulfide/selenide, metal nitride, metal phosphide and other derived electrocatalysts). At the end of this article, we also propose some viewpoints and prospects for the future development and research directions of HCD electrocatalysts for HER. Graphical Abstract This review summarizes the various effective design strategies for constructing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalysts under high current density (HCD), and the future development of HCD electrocatalysts for HER is discussed. Keywords Electrocatalyst High current density Hydrogen evolution reaction Water electrolysis 1 Introduction Energy has always been an important factor in promoting the development and progress of human society. Hydrogen (H2) is a renewable clean energy resource with a high weight energy density (146 kJ g–1), and the development of hydrogen production through water electrolysis is of great significance in solving environmental problems and promoting social development. Highly efficient and stable HER electrocatalyst is crucial to achieving large-scale H2 production [1,2]. After decades of research, researchers have made substantial progress in developing and exploring new HER electrocatalysts. However, most of these HER electrocatalysts are studied under low current density (no more than 500 mA cm–2) in laboratory conditions [3,4]. Generally speaking, the current density required for industrial electrolysis of water for H2 production is often not less than 500 mA cm–2. Moreover, whether electrocatalyst can work stably for a long time is also a issue that must be considered in industrial production. A higher current density means a faster and more complex reaction process, which changes some conditions in the reaction system, thereby affecting the catalytic activity and long-term stability of the electrocatalyst. Many current studies on low current density HER electrocatalysts have unsatisfactory catalytic performance under HCD conditions. In order to adapt the HER electrocatalysts to HCD conditions, it is necessary to analyze some important influencing factors in the HCD reaction process and optimize them accordingly. Optimization of the single physical properties of the electrocatalysts at low current density usually cannot lead to the improvement of the HCD performance of electrocatalysts, because the activity and stability of electrocatalysts will also be affected by the reaction system conditions, which is highly related to the current density. There is a great difference between the research of electrocatalysts at low current density and the HCD electrocatalysts required in actual industrial production. For the practical application of hydrogen production by water electrolysis, the research of HCD electrocatalysts is a very important aspect. In the past few years, more and more electrocatalysts have been designed and tested, but only a few studies on electrocatalysts have been conducted under HCD conditions. Obviously, considering the significance of HCD electrocatalysts for industrial scale water electrolysis, more efforts should be put into the research of HCD electrocatalysts. The core issue of HCD electrocatalysts is how to design them, and it is also necessary to have sufficient excellent electrocatalytic performance support in order to have the possibility of practical application. Therefore, when selecting and analyzing published research cases, this article will start with their performance, discuss the relevant factors that affect their performance, and combine them with HCD design strategies to analyze their performance optimization principles. In this article, we summarize the HER electrocatalysts that have been successfully developed in recent years and exhibit excellent catalytic performance under HCD conditions. Among them, we classify these HCD electrocatalysts into alloy, metal oxide, metal hydroxide, metal sulfide/selenide, metal nitrate and metal phosphide, and other derived electrocatalysts based on the type of compound. We analyze and discuss the characteristics of different types of HCD electrocatalysts. Finally, we also discuss the challenges and development directions faced by HCD electrocatalysis, which is expected to provide assistance and reference for future research on HCD electrocatalysts. 2 Design strategies and consideration of electrocatalysts 2.1 The difference between low current and HCD conditions Catalytic activity and long-term stability are extremely important and intuitive indicators for evaluating the performance of electrocatalysts, especially under HCD conditions. As shown in Fig. 1 , how to improve catalytic activity in engineering and maintain long-term stability have always been the core challenge faced by HCD electrocatalyst design. The factors that can directly affect the catalytic activity of HER are the number of active sites and intrinsic activity of the electrocatalyst, especially under HCD conditions, where more intense reactions have higher requirements for the number of active sites and intrinsic activity. The long-term decrease in HER stability is mainly caused by the loss of surface active sites and the damage to the physical structure of the electrocatalyst, especially under HCD conditions. More intense reactions have higher requirements for the stability of the morphology and structure of the electrocatalyst, the stability of active sites, the stability of the physical properties of the conductive substrate, and the connection strength between the active substance and the conductive substrate. Therefore, this article will summarize and analyze how to enhance the long-term stability of HER electrocatalysts under HCD conditions from the above four points. HER is a reaction that occurs at the cathode in the water electrolysis, and the most important step is the adsorption process of H* intermediate, which greatly affects the HER catalytic performance of the electrocatalyst. In addition to performance, the cost of electrocatalysts is also an important factor that must be considered. At present, the materials and instruments used for synthesizing HCD electrocatalysts are still relatively expensive, and the synthesis methods are also cumbersome with problems of long time consumption and low yield. Excessive costs will inevitably hinder large-scale production and industrial applications, leading to an increase in hydrogen prices. Therefore, attention should be paid to explore simple synthesis methods of non precious metal materials. For example, joule heating and microwave methods can be used to synthesize electrocatalysts in a short time, and etching method can also be employed to prepare a large amount of electrocatalysts at once. Future research should place greater emphasis on the speed of the synthesis process and the yield of electrocatalysts. 2.2 Factors affecting performance of electrocatalysts The reaction environment has a great impact on electrocatalyst, and these factors include temperature, pH, current density, etc. The impact of HCD on electrocatalysts mainly includes two aspects. Firstly, HCD usually causes electrocatalysts to be in a state of serious polarization for a long time, which is far away from the equilibrium potential, and significantly affect the catalytic activity of the electrocatalyst [5–8]. Secondly, HCD also affects the mass and electron transfer process at the interface between electrocatalysts surface and the reaction environment. HCD means that more and more hydrogen will be released from electrocatalysts surface. In this process, part of electrocatalysts surface will be covered by hydrogen bubbles and cannot contact the liquid environment. The coverage area of bubbles increases with the increase of current density, hindering the contact between the catalyst surface and the electrolyte, which is seriously detrimental to the reaction process. Moreover, too fast consumption of reactants on the surface of electrocatalysts may also cause the decrease of reactant concentration, and this phenomenon will cause the reduction of catalytic activity [9–14]. HCD will also affect the stability of electrocatalysts, and the bubbles generated on electrocatalysts surface will cause physical erosion on electrocatalysts surface when they are separated. With the increase of current density, the generation and separation speed of bubbles will also increase, which will cause the damage of surface structure of electrocatalysts, thus reducing the electrocatalysts and stability. From the perspective of reaction pathways, the impact of pH changes on the HER process is mainly reflected in the differences in reaction pathways. The active sites on electrocatalysts in acidic electrolytes will directly adsorb H + from the electrolyte, and H+ will generate H* after obtaining electrons. In non acidic environments, the adsorption of H2O is carried out first, and after obtaining electrons, H2O generates OH ‒ and H*. The additional adsorption process has higher requirements for electronic structure and transfer rate, which will to some extent affect the HER catalytic performance under HCD conditions. So most HER electrocatalysts exhibit better catalytic performance in acidic electrolytes. When designing and preparing HCD electrocatalysts, researchers often face the following challenges: (1) Some electrocatalysts themselves do not have high HER activity, and these electrocatalysts need to undergo phase transformation during the reaction process to generate true HER active species. For this type of electrocatalyst, the rate of phase transition also affects the catalytic activity. (2) As a large number of bubbles are generated on the electrocatalysts surface, a part of the electrocatalysts surface will not be able to contact the electrolyte, and the surface structure will also be eroded. Thus, when designing electrocatalysts, it is necessary to consider their surface properties, such as their hydrophilicity, gasiphobicity. (3) Meanwhile, the rapid HER under HCD conditions will consume a large amount of electrons and electrolytes, which requires a fast mass transfer process and rapid charge transfer rate of electrocatalysts. (4) Under the condition of HCD, the rapid reaction will produce more heat, and the temperature in the reaction system will inevitably rise. In most cases, the increase of temperature will also affect the stability, but in the stability and activity test of the electrocatalysts, the change of temperature will often be ignored. (5) Under HCD conditions, changes in pH value will also have a greater impact on the performance of electrocatalysts than at low current densities. The catalytic performance of the same electrocatalyst in acidic, neutral, and alkaline solutions may differ significantly. Meanwhile, due to the fast reaction rate, the pH value near the catalyst surface will also change. 2.3 Evaluating indicator of electrocatalysts In order to meet the requirements of industrial production, electrocatalysts need to have the following characteristics: (1) The electrocatalysts need to have excellent activity, thus reaching HCD at low overpotential. (2) The cost of materials used to produce electrocatalysts should be low, and the synthesis process should be as simple as possible with low energy consumption. (3) The electrocatalysts have a reliable three-dimensional structure, which is conducive to the separation of bubbles. (4) The electrocatalysts and the substrate are tightly assembled and not easy to separate, and the electrocatalysts need to have strong corrosion resistance in acidic or alkaline solution, and these enables the electrocatalyst to achieve long-term stability. (5) Electrocatalysts should be easy to recycle, reducing resource waste and environmental pollution. (6) Low charge transfer resistance (R ct) is also a feature of HCD electrocatalysts, the electron transfer process can be adjusted by constructing the electron transfer path, thus reducing the R ct. Therefore, an excellent HER electrocatalyst for HCD usually needs to have the above mentioned advantages [15–23]. In HER process, H∗ is a necessary reaction intermediate, and the adsorption capacity of H∗ is an important performance evaluation standard. Generally speaking, when the hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔG H*) of the electrocatalysts lower than 0, and the smaller the absolute value of ΔG H*, the more conducive to the catalytic process. At this time, electrocatalysts usually show excellent catalytic activity, and the amount of energy required for the adsorption and desorption process of the reaction intermediate on the electrocatalysts largely determines the performance of the electrocatalysts. In addition, the cost of raw materials and production process are also a factor that must be taken into account because the economic benefits of the electrocatalyst actually used in industrial production need to be considered. Under the condition of HCD, the overpotential and stability in the catalytic reaction process are two important indicators of the performance of the electrocatalysts. The above factors must be considered when designing HCD electrocatalysts, and any single factor change can cause changes in performance. In order to design excellent HCD electrocatalysts, a multifaceted and multi-scale design strategy is indispensable. 2.4 General synthesis method of electrocatalysts Based on current research, we have summarized some commonly used methods to synthesize electrocatalyst, which can to some extent guide the targeted design of HER electrocatalysts applied to HCD. (1) The hydrothermal or solvent thermal synthesis method can replace some high-temperature solid-state reactions by increasing the pressure and temperature of the reaction vessel. The hydrothermal method can uniformly grow electrocatalysts on conductive substrates, while also make it easier to form regular morphology. One step hydrothermal synthesis of single (multiple) metal heterojunctions can be achieved by adding multiple metal or non-metallic salts to the solvent. After hydrothermal synthesis, the next step of synthesis can also be controlled to synthesize various types of electrocatalysts. For example, after hydrothermal synthesis of materials containing hydroxides, high-temperature calcination in air can convert them into corresponding oxides, and further electrodeposition or hydrothermal synthesis can form various heterogeneous structures, including core-shell structures. (2) The electrodeposition method can effectively prepare high-purity and uniform electrocatalysts on conductive substrates. The morphology, aperture and composition of electrocatalysts can be controlled by adjusting the voltage, duration, electrolyte concentration, and other conditions during the electrodeposition process. However, electrodeposition also suffers from issues such as long processing time and low yield. (3) The high-temperature calcination method is also a commonly used method, which uses high-temperature heating equipment such as tube furnaces and muffle furnaces for high-temperature synthesis. We can adjust the composition and morphology of the electrocatalyst to a certain extent by changing the atmosphere, temperature, and duration, or by adding sulfur, phosphorus, and nitrogen elements upwind in the tubular furnace to achieve the sulfurization, phosphating, and nitriding of the electrocatalyst. Moreover, high-temperature calcination is also an effective method for manufacturing defects. However, this method also has problems such as poor controllability, long time consumption, high energy consumption, low yield, and susceptibility to agglomeration. (4) The molten salt synthesis method can cause some materials with lower melting points to react at the atomic level, effectively accelerating the diffusion of ions and transforming solid-phase reactions into liquid-phase reactions. It has the advantages of simplicity, safety, uniform product, high purity, and regular crystal morphology. However, the molten salt method also has problems such as low yield, high drug consumption, and low controllability. (5) Etching methods can be used to etch conductive substrates using corrosive solutions (such as acid, NaHS, high valence metal salts, etc.). This method can quickly and massively produce electrocatalysts with good repeatability, and it can also realize the doping of high valence metal cations. Compared to other methods, the etching method does not have a significant impact on the mechanical properties of the conductive substrate, but the in-situ growth of electrocatalysts are mainly composed of compounds containing elements in the conductive substrate itself, and the layer is thin. However, etching also faces issues such as irregular morphology, uneven catalyst growth, and poor controllability. 2.5 Design strategies of electrocatalysts In general, there are four strategies that can enhance the catalytic activity in HCD condition (Fig. 2 ), including modulation of morphology, substrates, heteroatom doping, and surface properties. Firstly, the morphology of the electrocatalyst has a greater impact on its catalytic performance. A special morphology (such as 1D nanowires, 2D nanosheets and 3D nanospheres or nanoflower) can provide a large specific surface area, thus exposing more catalytic active sites [29–34]. Moreover, especially for HCD electrocatalysts, the special self-supported structure can effectively enhance the long-term stability of electrocatalysts. Manthiram et al. [35] prepared a NiFe nanoclusters layered metal/carbon composites with Ni active sites (noted as hier-NiFe@sCNTs), and the overpotential of hier-NiFe@sCNTs at HCD of 500 mA cm–2 is 159 mV, which is lower than that of Pt/C. The hier-NiFe@sCNTs also shows excellent stability, and its attenuation is almost negligible after 30 h of operation. The special layered 1D morphology structure of hier-NiFe@sCNTs is conducive to the diffusion of electrolyte to the electrode, effectively optimizing the charge transfer process. Wang et al. [36] synthesized ultrathin porous two-dimensional Ni3Fe nitride lateral nanosheets (noted as Ni3Fe nitride), and the performance of Ni3Fe nitride at HCD over 600 mA cm–2 is better than that of Pt/C in 1 mol L–1 KOH solution. The outstanding HER activity of Ni3Fe nitride is largely attributed to the large specific surface area of porous nanosheets. Our group [37] reported a P-doped S-rich vacancy 2H-MoS2 nanoflowers. Benefiting from the large specific surface area of nanoflowers, it exhibits excellent HER catalytic performance. HCD has higher requirements for electron transfer and mass transfer processes. Some special substrates (such as nickel foam (NF), iron foam (IF), copper foam (CF) and carbon cloth (CC)) usually have a large number of tiny pores, which can increase the active site and accelerate the mass transfer. At the same time, these special substrates themselves have excellent conductivity, which accelerates the electron transfer process [38–45]. Yin et al. [46] reported a NiO/RuO2 nanoflakes, which is in-situ grown on NF (NiO/RuO2/NF). This structure has a rough surface and many tiny pores, which improves mass transfer efficiency. The NiO/RuO2/NF exhibits an outstanding HER activity, which only needs 178 mV to deliver the HCD of 1000 mA cm–2, even better than Pt/C. The overpotential of NiO/RuO2/NF increases by 90 mV after continuous operation at 1500 mA cm–2 for 72 h, and the reduction of stability may be due to the dissolution of electrocatalyst surface. In the prepared NiO/RuO2/NF catalyst, the NF substrate forms a rough porous surface structure for the growth of NiO/RuO2 on it, thus effectively enhancing the electrocatalytic performance of NiO/RuO2/NF at HCD. The third strategy is to add other metal or non-metal elements into the electrocatalysts to adjust the electronic structure, thus reducing the energy required for the adsorption of reaction intermediates on the electrocatalysts surface and realizing the enhancement of catalytic activity. Especially, doping a small amount of noble metal elements (Pt, Ru, Rh, Ir, etc) into the electrocatalysts can significantly improve the activity at HCD. Yu et al. [47] designed a heterostructured vacancy rich V-doped NiFe LDH nanosheet array (noted as P-V-NiFe LDH NSA). The overpotential of P-V-NiFe LDH NSA at 500 mA cm–2 is almost equal to Pt/C for HER. The doping of V optimized electronic structure, thus accelerating charge transfer rate and also enhancing the synergistic effect of P-V-NiFe and LDH NSA. Our group [48] reported a Ru-doped FeP4 nanosheets on iron (noted as Ru-FeP4/IF). Ru-FeP4/IF exhibited excellent catalytic activity in different electrolytes, which can achieve a HCD of 1000 mA cm–2 at the overpotential of 296 and 318 mV in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH and 1.0 mol L–1 KOH + seawater, respectively. The presence of Ru played a role in chemisorption and size regulation of FeP4, and also adjusted the electronic structure to reduce the adsorption energy barrier of the reaction intermediate. The fourth strategy is to change the surface properties of electrocatalysts, thereby improving its hydrophilicity, aerophobicity, charge transfer rate, mass transfer process, and other properties [49–52]. Ru/MXene three-dimensional electrode (Ru/c-Ti3C2T x /NF) with both super aerophobicity and super hydrophilicity was prepared by Li et al. [53], and the Ru/c-Ti3C2T x /NF can achieve the HCD of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2 at overpotentials of 219 and 320 mV, respectively. The superhydrophilicity and superaerophobicity of Ru/c-Ti3C2T x /NF result in excellent catalytic activity and stability, which is beneficial for the electrolyte to continuously replenish around Ru/c-Ti3C2T x /NF and for the detachment of bubbles on the surface of Ru/c-Ti3C2T x /NF. Besides, hydrogen overflow is an engineering design strategy unique to HER electrocatalysts. Hydrogen overflow adsorbs H* intermediates on one active site, and then H* is transferred to another active site for desorption and generation of H2. This method effectively solves the adverse effect of a single active site on H* adsorption energy that is too strong or too weak, allowing sites that were originally difficult to adsorb H + to become effective HER active sites. The separation of adsorption and desorption can also make the active sites less susceptible to destruction in the rapid reaction of HCD. 3 Key aspects to consider in designing HCD catalysts The active substance of an electrocatalyst is essentially a thin film attached to the carrier, and each active substance unit needs to be assembled onto the carrier through some logic. This article summarizes and discusses some key factors that affect the performance of HCD electrocatalysts in the following sections, including the morphology, size, surface chemistry, electron transfer, and electrolyte environment of the electrocatalysts (Fig. 3 ). The microstructure and macroscopic structure of the assembled active material layer directly determine the surface morphology, electronic channels, material channels, and the number of exposed active sites of the electrocatalyst (Fig. 4 ). For HER catalytic reactions, all design strategies and mechanisms are centered around the contact surface between the electrocatalyst and electrolyte, electron transfer of the electrocatalyst, and material transfer, which are the three most fundamental factors that directly affect the catalytic performance of HER (Fig. 4(a)). This section will focus on describing the differences between HCD and low current density, and analyze how these factors affect the catalytic performance of HCD electrocatalysts based on recent research progress. 3.1 Catalyst electrolyte interaction In the HCD environment, the interaction between electrolytes and electrocatalysts is an important factor affecting catalytic performance. The mass transfer efficiency and the adsorption desorption process between reaction intermediates and catalytic active sites are all manifestations of the interaction between electrolytes and electrocatalysts. By adjusting the inner Helmholtz plane, adding Lewis acid-base pairs to the system, and adsorbing ion groups on the surface, the interactions at the interface can be affected, thereby regulating the catalytic performance of HCD. As mentioned earlier, the pH value of the electrolyte can have an impact on the HCD catalytic performance of the electrocatalyst. In addition to adjusting the overall pH value of the electrolyte, some methods can also be used to adjust the local pH value at the contact interface between the electrocatalyst and the electrolyte. Firstly, the surface of the point catalyst adsorbs some ion clusters to form a surface layer with positive or negative charges, thereby changing the pH value of the contact surface between the electrocatalyst and the electrolyte. Secondly, by introducing Lewis acid/base, the pH value of the contact surface between the electrocatalyst and electrolyte can also be adjusted and changed. Liu et al. [54] synthesized amorphous/crystalline CeO2 with surface dispersed Ru clusters CeO2–δ (Ru/ac-CeO2–δ ) HER electrocatalysts accelerate the desorption of OH from VO sites through a water assisted proton exchange pathway, thereby improving the kinetics of alkaline HER. Due to the presence of unique oxygen vacancies (VO) and Ru Lewis acid-base pairs (LABPs), the alkaline HER kinetics can be significantly improved. VO as a Lewis acid site is beneficial for water adsorption and H–OH bond cleavage, while weak Lewis alkaline Ru clusters are beneficial for hydrogen desorption. This selective active site is very beneficial for dealing with the adverse effects of the interaction between electrocatalysts and electrolytes (Fig. 4(b)). Yang et al. [59] designed an efficient electrocatalyst for the coupling of Ceylon patterned layered Ni(PO3)2-Ni2P modified with single crystal NiMoO4 nanorods and MoO x self-supported catalysts. MoO x gradually dissolves with HER reaction, further exposing more nickel sites, Lewis base sites, and in-situ forming hydroxyl ligand surface loaded nanoparticles, Lewis acid sites, which promote the adsorption process of H* and H2O, respectively. In addition, electron transfer causes a downward shift in the d-band center of Ni, which helps optimize the desorption ability of H*. Similarly, utilizing the Lewis acid bond pairing effect to design selective active sites in electrocatalysts is beneficial for optimizing the intermediate adsorption process. Coating a layer of material that is beneficial for enhancing the catalytic activity or preventing corrosion of electrocatalysts is also an effective design method. Surface coating materials may not necessarily participate in catalytic processes as active sites, but they can help improve catalytic performance. Xiong et al. [60] coated a layer of phytic acid (NF) on the surface of Ni3N nanosheet arrays/ Ni3N@NiFe-PA. The surface coated phytic acid acts as a proton transfer relay, changing the electron cloud density of Ni sites and accelerating the catalytic process. The interaction between interfacial water and surface active substances of electrocatalysts in IHP can alter local substance concentration and surface adsorption energy, which adjusts the catalytic performance of HCD. The magnitude of overpotential can alter the effect of IHP on the adsorption energy of intermediates in electrocatalyst reactions, alter the formation and cleavage processes of chemical bonds and intermediates. Designing a reaction interface to prioritize attracting reactants to IHP is highly effective for optimizing HER reaction kinetics. Jiang et al. [55] also constructed a charge polarized Ni0.2Mo0.8N/Ni electrocatalyst. The interface synergy and the enhanced k-ion concentration at the tip within IHP are the main reasons for the excellent performance of HER (Fig. 4(c)). Ge et al. [56] established a MoS2 anionic surface (Pd, Ru-MoS2–x OH y ) with molecular substitution controlled by –OH at the S site –OH groups form strong non covalent hydrogen bonds with H2O or H3O+, endowing the interface with reactant drag function (Fig. 4(d)). The special anionic surface combines with active S atoms as active sites, resulting in excellent HER catalytic performance. The anionic surface created in this study represents an effective dual functional interface for improving kinetic performance, with atomic mixing of active sites and drag function of reactants. At present, most studies use pure water as electrolyte, and there are no other interfering substances except for the added drugs, but there are also some studies that focus on discussing the application of electrocatalysts in seawater. There are various interfering substances in seawater, including Cl–, Ca2+, Mg2+, which can cause changes in the properties of the contact surface between electrocatalysts and electrolytes. Generally speaking, the HER process in seawater is mainly influenced by Ca2+ and Mg2+. As the reaction progresses, different degrees of precipitation will be generated on the surface of the HER electrocatalyst, which will cover the catalytic active sites and seriously affect the activity and stability of the electrocatalyst. Tang et al. investigated the hydrophobic nanocatalysts (noted as NCP/PC) on Pinewood derived carbon (PC), which exhibit excellent HER catalytic performance in 1 mol L–1 KOH+seawater and pure seawater without generating precipitation on the surface. In 1 mol L–1 KOH+seawater, it can reach 1000 mA cm–2 at 145 mV. In pure seawater, it can reach 500 mA cm–2 at 550 mV. The porous structure of PC optimize the mechanical processes on the contact surface between the electrocatalyst and seawater, promote the separation of bubbles on the surface of NCP/PC, and thus leading to excellent precipitation rejection ability of NCP/PC. 3.2 Path of electronic transmission The speed of electron transfer greatly affects the HCD catalytic performance of electrocatalysts. In addition to adjusting the electron distribution structure, shortening the electron transfer path is also an effective method. This can not only affect the electron transfer process between the active site of the electrocatalyst and the reaction intermediate, but also affect the electron transfer process between the electrocatalyst and the carrier [61]. The catalytic activity of electrocatalysts is a manifestation of conductivity, so improving the conductivity of catalyst materials or carriers is also a common method to enhance the catalytic performance of HCD. In addition to selecting materials with higher conductivity, methods to change material conductivity include lattice strain, defect engineering, and heteroatom doping engineering. Yu et al. [62] prepared Mo-doped NiS/Ni3S2 with rich S vacancies, which can work stably at HCD for HER. The intensity of the S–H peak on the surface of Mo NiS/Ni3S2 catalyst increases over time, and the presence of S vacancies can slow down the rate of enhancement of the S–H peak intensity. The enhanced intensity of the surface S–H peak means the accumulation of S–H, leading to surface poisoning of the electrocatalyst, which is not conducive to the HER catalytic process. The S vacancy has the effect of inhibiting the formation of S–H bonds, reducing the toxic effect of S–H bonds on the electrocatalyst surface, optimizing the desorption step of H*, enhancing electronic interactions between heterogeneous interfaces, and thus promoting the HER catalytic activity at HCD. Chen et al. [57] synthesized a two-phase heterostructured polymorphic sulfide on nickel foil (noted as Pd4S-Ni3S2/HPNF) for HER. Pd4S-Ni3S2/HPNF shows excellent HER performance in the test and can reach the HCD of 500 mA cm–2 at the overpotential of only 247 mV. The interface effect reduces the d-band value of Pd4S-Ni3S2/HPNF, and a lower d-band value means better hydrogen evolution ability (Fig. 4(e)). The heterogeneous interface effect optimizes the electron transfer process and accelerates the electron transfer dynamics. A phosphide nanostructure electrocatalyst containing Ni, Co, and Fe (noted as Ni-Co-Fe-P NBs) was reported by Wei et al. [63]. The doping of Fe and Ni optimized the conductivity of the electrocatalyst, altered the electron transfer process, and promoted the formation of high valence active sites. The HER electrocatalytic activity of Ni-Co-Fe-P NBs is measured, and the overpotential of Ni-Co-Fe-P NBs at HCD of 800 mA cm–2 is only 190 mV. Co4+ is an important catalytic active site in Ni-Co-Fe-P NBs, and the doped Fe and Ni can effectively promote the production of Co4+, thus optimizing the HER catalytic performance of Ni-Co-Fe-P NBs. The Ni-Co-Fe-P NBs has the potential for practical HER at HCD. Chen et al. [64] used magnetic-field-focused atmospheric-pressure plasma jets in oxygen-argon gas mixtures to fix nanosized Ni-Co bimetallic oxide nanoparticles on the Ni-Co bimetallic hydroxide nanosheet (named as NiCo2O4@NiCo(OH)2/PNCF). As a result, NiCo2O4@NiCo(OH)2/PNCF can reach HCD of 500 mA cm–2 at overpotential of 691 mV, and the LSV curves only decay ≍ 5.8% after 10000 CV test at HCD of 500 mA cm–2 for HER. Therefore, the special gas plasma synthesis method enhances the bonding strength and is conducive to enhancing the catalytic stability of HCD. For NiCo2O4/NiCo(OH)2, the activity of Ni site is higher than that of Co site. The Ni active sites have the effect of accelerating the electron transfer process, and the introduction of Ni also increases the electron density of Co active sites in Co(OH)2, which is the reason for excellent catalytic performance at HCD. Generally speaking, the resistance between the active material of an electrocatalyst and the conductive carrier is small, which can provide or absorb electrons for the active material, promoting electron transfer at the interface. The basis for semiconductor materials to be used in the design of electrocatalysts is to rely on conductive carriers to enhance conductivity. The thickness and size of electrocatalysts are related to the length of electron transfer paths and are key factors affecting conductivity, especially effective for semiconductor materials. Huang et al. [51] prepared a dual-functional niobium doped nickel phosphide nanosheet electrocatalysts on dielectric barrier discharge plasmas treated NF (noted as Ni12P5-Fe2P-NbP/PNF). The overpotentials of Ni12P5-Fe2P-NbP/PNF at HCD of 800 mA cm–2 is 311 mV. According to the above results, the outstanding HER catalytic performance of Ni12P5-Fe2P-NbP/PNF at HCD can be explained as follows: (1) The interface between three metal phosphides exposes more HER active sites, (2) the decrease of R ct accelerates the electron diffusion ability, (3) the Nb-doped in Ni12P5-Fe2P-NbP/PNF reduces the energy barrier of H* adsorption (Fig. 4(f)). The above design methods can effectively optimize the electron transfer process without changing the electron transfer path. Recently, an increasing number of studies have proposed design methods for guiding electron transfer through the construction of electronic bridges. This method can control the electron density of some metal active sites, alleviate the adverse effects of excessive valence state changes during the reaction process, such as reduced intrinsic activity and dissolution of active sites. Meng et al. [58] reported an amorphous MoO x /Co(OH)2 HER electrocatalyst. During the HER reaction process, interface reconstruction causes Mo4+ to increase to Mo6+, thereby forming Co–O–Mo bridging oxygen bonds, guiding electrons to enrich at O and transforming O into the HER catalytic active site (Fig. 4(g)). MoO x /Co(OH)2 can work stably for 10000 h at HCD of 500 mA cm–2. Xing et al. [65] designed a Ti doped IrO x /Ir electrocatalyst (Ti-IrO x /Ir). The Ti site provides electrons to weaken the Ir–O interaction, which can enhance the catalytic activity of the Ir site and help improve its stability. Peng et al. [66] constructed adjustable carriers through non stoichiometric engineering to stabilize ruthenium nanoparticles and synthesized Ru/Ti4O7 electrocatalysts. The corrosion resistance of Ru was enhanced by the electron enrichment of stable Ti-O-Ru units, and the surface was reconstructed to form amorphous RuO x with high activity, which improved the catalytic activity and stability of Ru/Ti4O7. 3.3 Dimensionality Single atoms, nanoparticles, nanowires, nanotubes, and nanosheets are the most basic low dimensional structures. Due to its high specific surface area and short electron transfer path, low dimensional structures have become an effective strategy for designing HCD electrocatalysts. The one-dimensional surface structure can provide selectivity, and single atom electrocatalysts have excellent atomic catalytic efficiency and mass activity (Fig. 5(a) ). On this basis, attaching a single atom to a three-dimensional self-supporting structure can balance catalytic activity and stability. The two-dimensional structure makes it easy to stack, making it easy to mass produce. Not only that, low dimensional structures can also flexibly form three-dimensional structures. Especially the self-supporting structure can effectively enhance the long-term stability of HCD electrocatalysts. Specifically, low dimensional structures are beneficial for increasing the number of active sites and accelerating the reaction rate on the surface of electrocatalysts. In addition, the rapid electron transfer of low dimensional electrocatalysts also has a positive impact on enhancing intrinsic activity. We can control the number and electronic structure of unsaturated coordination atoms on the surface of electrocatalysts by designing heteroatom doping, lattice strain, particle size, and ligand effects. The variation of local substance concentration on the surface of low dimensional electrocatalysts can affect the local chemical potential, which can optimize catalytic performance. Some sufficiently small low dimensional electrocatalysts, due to their small gas-liquid contact surface, are more conducive to the detachment of bubbles generated during the reaction process, thereby weakening the erosion of surface substances by bubbles and promoting mass transfer which can effectively improve the catalytic performance of HCD. Single atom electrocatalysts have the highest atomic utilization efficiency, and designing precious metals as single atom electrocatalysts can efficiently utilize their excellent performance. Zhang et al. [67] prepared 1.89 wt% low Pt loaded PtM/p-GO single atom electrocatalysts using non thermal plasma technology (Fig. 5(b)). This electrocatalyst can reach 1000 mA cm–2 at an overpotential of 130 mV, while also exhibiting good long-term stability. Feng et al. [68] captured Ru nanoparticles (NP) and single atoms (SA) using a solvothermal method (Figs. 5(c)–(e)). Optimized product (RuNP-RuSA@CFN-800) has excellent electrocatalytic performance for alkaline hydrogen evolution reactions. Even at high current densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2, the overpotential is only 154 and 251 mV, respectively. The electronic synergistic effect between Ru NP and SA can be regulated RuNPRuSA@CFN-800. The charge distribution optimized the intermediate adsorption process, thereby accelerating the hydrogen evolution process. On top of this, low dimensional structures can be assembled into high-dimensional 3D structures, which combine the advantages of low dimensional structures in electrocatalysts. They can simultaneously balance electrolyte contact, bubble detachment, exposure of active sites, and shortening of electron transfer pathways. In the design of HCD electrocatalysts, constructing a self-supporting three-dimensional structure is an effective strategy to improve the catalytic performance of HCD. 3.4 Nano, micro, and macro structures The influence of surface chemistry of electrocatalysts on HCD performance was introduced earlier, and further combined with the dimensional factors of electrocatalysts, the micro and macro structures of electrocatalysts are also very important influencing factors. The design of electrocatalyst channels can optimize the bubble detachment and mass transfer processes of electrocatalysts, thereby enhancing their HER catalytic performance in HCD (Fig. 6(a) ). For example, Zhang et al. [69] synthesized a Cr-Co x P three-dimensional self-supporting nanosheet electrocatalyst, which reached 1000 mA cm–2 at an overpotential of 404 mV. Before doping with Cr, the surface of Co x P exhibits a nanowire morphology with a diameter of approximately 100–200 nm. After Cr doping, the morphology and structure of Cr-Co x P changed to nanosheets with a thickness of 12 nm, which resulted in a larger specific surface area of Cr-Co x P and optimized its HER electrocatalytic performance in HCD (Figs. 6(b) and 6(c)). Li et al. [70] reported a porous heterostructure Ni3S2-NiFe LDH nanosheet, where the microstructure of the heterojunction interface resulted in excellent hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity of Ni3S2-NiFe LDH (Figs. 6(d) and 6(e)), leading to excellent HER catalytic performance. Compared with the precursor NiFe LDHs/NF, the water contact angle of Ni3S2-NiFe LDH was optimized from 87° to nearly 0°. Not only that, the bubbles that precipitate on the surface of Ni3S2-NiFe LDH during the reaction process are also smaller. So far, various catalyst/carrier structures have been synthesized, and many studies have shown that nano, micro, and macro structure improvement engineering is an effective approach for designing HCD electrocatalysts [71]. 3.5 Surface chemistry The surface chemical properties of electrocatalysts are important factors affecting their HCD catalytic performance. Design strategies such as component regulation, defect engineering, heteroatom doping, lattice strain, and heterostructure engineering can alter the surface chemical properties of electrocatalysts, thereby affecting intermediate adsorption and mass transfer processes [44,74–79]. In addition, other substances attached to the surface of electrocatalysts can also affect their surface chemical properties, and these attachments may not necessarily have catalytic activity. Adhesives can affect the valence state and bond energy of electrocatalysts by providing or absorbing electrons, and adjust the binding strength of intermediates at catalytic sites. Research progress indicates that surface chemical engineering is an important factor affecting HER electrocatalysts used for HCD (Fig. 7(a) ). It is worth noting that the HER reaction has a shorter process compared to the OER reaction and requires less electron transfer, which makes adjusting the surface chemistry of the electrocatalyst more intuitive. Combining crystalline and amorphous phases is a typical method of surface electrochemical regulation of HCD catalytic performance. Wang et al. [72] constructed Pt, Co co doped tungsten trioxide (Pt/N-CoWO3). Which regulates the electronic structure of Pt–N/O bonds, induces charge redistribution between tungsten trioxide and Pt NPs (Fig. 7(b)), promotes electron transfer, and optimizes the interaction between metal carriers, resulting in excellent HER catalytic performance of the electrocatalyst. Pt/N-CoWO3 can reach 1 and 2 A cm–2 at overpotentials of 94 and 108 mV, respectively. Co doping also regulates the morphology of the catalyst and optimizes the structural stability of CoWO3, enabling Pt/N-CoWO3 to operate stably at 1 A cm–2 for 2000 h. This electrocatalyst utilizes the disordered arrangement of amorphous phases to provide a large specific surface area and expose more active sites. The intrinsic activity of active sites and the long-term stability of electrocatalysts are enhanced by utilizing the better conductivity and stability of crystalline phases. Zhang et al. [80] synthesized amorphous molybdenum sulfide/nitrogen doped reduced graphene oxide nanocomposites (a-MoWS x /N-RGO) by adjusting plasma treatment time and chemical composition. The amorphous state optimizes the surface chemical properties of the electrocatalyst, with electrons preferentially aggregating towards the catalytic active site 2S2–. Meanwhile, tungsten doping also optimized the adsorption process of intermediate extraction. This enables a-MoWS x /N-RGO to achieve excellent HER catalytic performance, reaching 1000 mA cm–2 of HCD at a low overpotential of 348 mV. Jason Riley et al. [73] prepared lattice strain Bi2S3 with a three-dimensional hierarchical structure through topological transformation. The lattice spacing increases with the prolongation of vulcanization time (Fig. 7(b)). During the HER process, pseudo amorphous Bi is generated by edge reconstruction of Bi2S3 nanorods with lattice strain, further exposing more active sites. The expansion of lattice spacing reduces the bandwidth of Bi three-dimensional orbitals, leading to an increase in the center of the d band and promoting electron exchange with the S 2p orbitals (Fig. 7(c)). Deng et al. [81] designed and synthesized a series of NiS x Se1–x nanosheets@nanorod hybrid materials with uniform lattice strain. This three-dimensional nanostructure is beneficial for improving the conductivity of electrocatalysts. The NiS0.5Se0.5 ≍ 2.7% lattice strain exhibits outstanding HER catalytic activity. The lattice strain generated in this electrocatalyst reduces the d-orbital overlap of the metal, resulting in a narrow bandwidth edge and a d-band center closer to the Fermi level. This effectively optimizes the adsorption process of NiS0.5Se0.5 for H* intermediates. In most related studies, the lattice strain of electrocatalysts undergoes a synthesis process, and it is not discussed whether there will be any changes after the formation of lattice strain. Zou et al. [82] triggered the compression strain of their IrO6 by heating adjustment, which is completely different from the general method of generating constant strain in crystals. The thermally induced strain can be easily adjusted by changing temperature. The increase in temperature causes changes in the bond lengths of Ir‒O and Ir‒Ir, leading to adjustable strain in the polyhedral structure of IrO6 and a decrease in its d-band center. The lattice strain of the electrocatalyst in this study increases with temperature, and its HER catalytic activity also increases with temperature, which is a special type of temperature dependent lattice strain. How to develop new HCD electrocatalysts targeting the complex environment of industrial production and the demand for cost and efficiency should become a focus of future research. The above section describes the key factors that need to be considered when designing HCD electrocatalysts, which are the key intrinsic design factors that affect the activity and stability of HCD electrocatalysts. When designing HCD electrocatalysts, taking into account the above factors, it is possible to predict their catalytic performance and mechanism to a certain extent, which beneficial for the practical application of HER electrocatalysts in HCD. 4 Current status of HCD electrocatalysts for HER In recent years, research on HCD electrocatalysts has gradually increased, and researchers are increasingly paying attention to the practical applications of electrocatalysts. After a long time of exploration by researchers, many HCD electrocatalysts with excellent performance have been successfully developed (Fig. 8 ). According to the composition of the electrocatalysts, they can be divided into six categories: alloy, metal oxide, metal hydroxide, metal sulfide/selenide, metal nitride and metal phosphide, and these six types of electrocatalysts have some common or proprietary synthesis methods. In addition, different types of electrocatalysts also have their advantages and disadvantages for HCD (Fig. 9 ). 4.1 Metal alloy electrocatalysts Based on the amount of metal elements in alloy, metal alloy electrocatalysts are classified into bimetallic alloy, trimetallic alloy, tetrametallic alloy, and multi-metal alloy electrocatalysts. The commonly used synthesis methods for metal alloy electrocatalysts include mechanical alloying, hydrothermal, thermal decomposition reduction, electrodeposition, molten salt, etc. As for noble metal-based catalysts, compared with single-component noble metal electrocatalysts, multi-component noble metal electrocatalysts can not only save the amount of noble metal and reduce the cost, but also make use of the characteristics of different metal components to overcome the limitations of single-component materials in application [89]. Multi-component composite noble metal nanomaterials can combine stress effect, electronic effect with other synergistic effects between various metals, and can display more excellent catalytic performance than single-component noble metal nanomaterials in electrocatalysis. In practical exploration and research, since different metal atoms have different atomic arrangement, after forming the nanostructures, different metal atoms interact with each other, further optimizing and preparing electrocatalysts with excellent performance. This type of electrocatalyst usually has a unique nanostructure that provides large surface area, which enhances the stability of the electrocatalyst while exposing more active sites. In addition, many metal elements contained in metal alloy electrocatalysts can often optimize electronic structure and enhance conductivity, which is of great significance to enhance the HER activity of electrocatalysts at HCD. Therefore, metal alloy electrocatalysts have the following advantages, such as heat and corrosion resistance, fast electronic transmission rate, high hardness and high electronic conductivity, etc. However, metal alloy electrocatalysts still have some issues that need to be addressed, including particle agglomeration phenomenon, nanoparticles prone to detachment and metal particles easily oxidized, etc. Many binary alloy electrocatalysts composed of noble and transition metal elements have excellent HER catalytic performance. Chen et al. [85] synthesized IrFe nano-alloy on the carbon sheets (noted as IrFe/NC) with the Ir-loading of 23.74 wt%, and the overpotential of IrFe at HCD of 1000 mA cm–2 is 850 mV. It is proved that the addition of Fe atoms to pure Ir can effectively improve the catalytic performance of electrocatalyst. This study utilized the excellent catalytic performance of Ir to design a bimetallic alloy engineering, adjusted the electronic structure of Fe, changed the surface chemical properties of the electrocatalyst, and optimized the adsorption energy of intermediates. This enabled IrFe/NC to exhibit excellent HER catalytic performance under HCD conditions. On the basis of FeIr/NC alloy, Yin et al. [91] prepared a self-supported bimetallic FeIr metal alloy electrocatalyst on NF (noted as FeIr/NF) with the low Ir-loading of 0.936 wt%. As shown in the XRD pattern (Fig. 10(a) ), there are four diffraction peaks at 85.913, 71.061, 48.526, and 41.694°, indicating the successful synthesis of FeIr alloy. The performance of FeIr bimetallic alloy for HER is measured at HCD, and FeIr/NF reaches 500, 1000, 2000 and 3500 mA cm–2 at low overpotentials of 125, 204, 336, and 471 mV, respectively. This study also designed FeIr bimetallic alloys and adjusted the particle size of the alloy particles based on this, meanwhile, the ultra-low Ir load (0.936 wt%) ensured that the cost is not too high. Tiny FeIr alloy nanoparticles have a larger specific surface area, which can provide more active sites and ensure catalytic activity. Meanwhile, in terms of long-term stability, this study designed a self-supporting three-dimensional structure that does not rely on adhesives, strengthening the connection between active substances and conductive substrates, making the catalyst less susceptible to damage in rapid catalytic reactions. Yin et al. [90] also developed unique volcanic-like FeIr bimetallic alloy on NF (noted as FeIr/NF) with the lower Ir-loading of 0.546 wt%, which reduces the production cost of the FeIr/NF. Fig. 10(b) showed typical peaks of the three valence states of Fe, indicating the coexistence of multiple valence states of Fe in the alloy. This study provides a large number of active sites by designing a special self-supporting volcanic morphology structure with a large specific surface area. The volcanic morphology is also conducive to the rapid detachment of bubbles, reducing the catalytic activity decrease caused by the coverage of active sites by bubbles and the damage to the morphology structure during bubble detachment. Researchers have also developed a number of multi-component alloy HCD electrocatalysts containing more than three transition metal elements. Deka et al. [95] synthesized trimetallic FeCoPd polyhedral alloy nanoparticles using hydrothermal method. FeCoPd can deliver 1000 mA cm–2 at a low overpotential of 400 mV for HER. Kang et al. [96] reported a nanoporous tetra-metallic alloy electrocatalyst (noted as np-NiMnFeMo). np-NiMnFeMo shows a low overpotential of 178 mV at HCD of 500 mA cm–2 in 1 mol L–1 KOH solution. In addition, when the overpotential rises to 290 mV, the current density of np-NiMnFeMo reaches a higher value of 1000 mA cm–2. The synergistic effect between metal elements in np-NiMnFeMo adjusts the electronic structure of the electrocatalyst and reduces the ΔG H*. When alloy electrocatalysts contain no less than five different metal elements, they belong to high entropy alloys in alloy engineering, with better mechanical properties, regular crystal structure, corrosion resistance, and thermal stability. Meanwhile, the interaction between multiple metal atoms can also enhance its catalytic performance. Lu et al. [92] prepared a FeCoNiMnW high-entropy alloy on carbon papers (noted as H-FeCoNiMnW). Fig. 10(c) showed the LSV curves of Pt/C and H-FeCoNiMnW in 0.5 mol L–1 H2SO4 solution. Compared with M-FeCoNiMn and M-FeCoNiW, the H-FeCoNiMnW exhibits the best HER catalytic performance, which is close to Pt/C. The excellent electrocatalytic performance can be attributed to the synergistic effect between multiple metal atoms in the alloy, especially the protective effect of W in the alloy. W can form an in-situ protective layer in the HER process of acid medium, reducing the performance degradation caused by electrocatalyst dissolution, which can help to achieve high stability and catalytic performance at HCD. In addition, Yao et al. [97] also synthesized a CuAlNiMoFe five metal high-entropy alloy electrocatalyst with porous nanostructures structure. CuAlNiMoFe can achieve a HCD of 1840 mA cm–2 at overpotential of 240 mV. The influence of alloy engineering on the surface chemistry of electrocatalysts optimized the adsorption process of intermediates. 4.2 Metal oxide electrocatalysts Metal oxide is also an important and common type of electrocatalyst for HER at HCD. The commonly used synthesis methods for metal oxide electrocatalysts include mechanical alloying, hydrothermal, thermal decomposition reduction, electrodeposition, molten salt, etc. Metal oxide has a variety of composition and structure, which makes metal oxide electrocatalyst very flexible in the adjustment of electronic structure [98]. Metal oxide electrocatalysts have the following advantages, such as low cost and abundance, environmental friendliness, compositional or structural diversity and flexible tunability, etc. However, metal oxide electrocatalysts still have some issues that need to be addressed, including limited catalytic-active site, poor H+ adsorption capacity, poor electronic conductivity and unstable in acidic environments, etc. Mu et al. [93] have developed an ultra-low Ru loaded Co-based oxide (noted as Ru-CoO x /NF). Figs. 10(d) and 10(e) prove that Ru-CoO x /NF with amorphous phase was successfully synthesized. At the HCD of 1000 mA cm–2 (Fig. 10(f)), the overpotentials of Ru-CoO x /NF is 252. The outstanding HER performance of Ru-CoO x /NF at HCD can be attributed to two aspects: Firstly, because of the amorphous structure, Ru-CoO x /NF gets more active sites. Secondly, the doping of Ru promotes the charge transfer inside the catalyst and improves the electrochemical kinetics of Ru-CoO x /NF. Zhang et al. [94] reported Co-doped CeO2 nanosheets with a special 2D multilayer structure (noted as Co-doped CeO2), which showed excellent catalytic performance for HER at HCD. The overpotential of Co-doped CeO2 at HCD of 500 mA cm–2 is 215 mV. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy analyses prove that R ct of Co-doped CeO2 is the smallest (Fig. 10(g)), which means that Co doping has adjusted electronic structure of Co-doped CeO2 and effectively improve the charge transfer ability. The existence of Co doping causes the reduction of the formation energy of the oxygen vacancies, and oxygen vacancies make water more easily dissociate on surface of electrocatalyst, thus effectively enhancing the HER activity of Co-doped CeO2 at HCD. In a word, Co-doped CeO2 nanosheets have good HCD catalytic performance and stability, which is suitable for industrial production. Iron oxide-based electrocatalysts are also commonly used in HER process. Chai et al. [25] reported a F, P co-doped Fe3O4 electrocatalyst (noted as F, P-Fe3O4). As displayed in Fig. 10(h), when the current density reaches 500, 1000, and 1500 mA cm–2, the overpotentials of the F, P-Fe3O4 are 277.6, 321.3, and 350.1 mV. The excellent performance of F, P-Fe3O4 at HCD can be attributed to three factors: (1) self-supporting structure reduces the loss caused by bubbles on the electrocatalyst surface, (2) defective structures expose more active sites, (3) the doped P and F enhances the intrinsic activity of Fe atoms. 4.3 Metal hydroxide electrocatalysts Metal hydroxide electrocatalyst is also an important type of electrocatalyst, and metal hydroxide consists of metal as cation and hydroxide ion as anion, in which common divalent metal cations include Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cd2+, Mn2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, and Pd2+ etc, and common trivalent metal cations include Fe3+, Co3+, Tb3+, V3+, and Mn3+ etc. The commonly used synthesis methods for metal hydroxide electrocatalysts include solvothermal or hydrothermal, electrodeposition, co-precipitation, microwave irradiation, intercalation chemistry, etc. Metal hydroxide electrocatalysts have the following advantages, such as hydrophily, unique layered structure, etc. However, metal hydroxide electrocatalysts still have some issues that need to be addressed, including poor stability in acidic environments, poor charge transfer ability, and low conductivity, etc. [99]. Wang et al. [100] used a simple gas templated electrodeposition method to prepare a core-shelled electrocatalysts (noted as NiCo/NiCo-OH) for HER. Notably, NiCo/NiCo-OH can reach 500 mA cm–2 at the low overpotential of 184 mV (Fig. 11(a) ), which is because the LDH layer on the electrocatalytic surface can enhance its HER catalytic performance. NiCo/NiCo-OH has no obvious performance loss after continuous operation of 24 h at the HCD of 500 mA cm–2 (Fig. 11(b)), showing the stability to adapt to industrial production. The core-shell structure can improve the electron transfer rate and expose more catalytic active sites on heterogeneous interfaces, which results in NiCo/NiCo-OH having outstanding HER catalytic performance under HCD conditions. Layered double hydroxides (LDH) are a research hotspot in metal hydroxide electrocatalysts. Shen et al. [101] adopted the strategy of one-step hydrothermal synthesis to prepare a self-supported hydrophilic NiFe-LDH nano-sheet array (noted as NiFe-LDH/NF-x). The LSV curves of NiFe-LDH-3.5 and Pt/C/NF are measured (Fig. 11(c)) at 500 mA cm–2, and the overpotentials are 330 and 406 mV, respectively. The following three aspects are the reasons for the outstanding HER performance of NiFe-LDH/NF-3.5: Firstly, NiFe-LDH/NF-3.5 has a favorable self-supported structure and super-large nano-sheet array, which exposes more active sites. Secondly, hydrophilicity of NiFe-LDH/NF-3.5 makes it easier for water molecules to be adsorbed on the electrocatalyst surface. Lastly, during preparation process, NF with good conductivity is used as the substrate, which improves the conductivity of NiFe-LDH/NF-3.5. Researchers can effectively improve the catalytic activity of LDH electrocatalysts by doping metal/non-metal atoms. Wu et al. [26] synthesized a B-doped NiCo LDH electrocatalyst (noted as A-NiCo LDH/NF) that can work stably at HCD on NF for HER. A-NiCo LDH/NF has large specific surface area due to its unique three-dimensional configuration and crystal-amorphous structure, which exposes more active sites. The B doping also adjusts electronic structure and accelerates the charge transfer rate of A-NiCo LDH/NF, which can reach HCD of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2 when the overpotentials are 286 and 381 mV, respectively, even better than Pt/C/NF and some other Ni/Co-based electrocatalysts (Fig. 11(d)). As illustrated in Fig. 11(e), the 72 h i-t test of A-NiCo LDH/NF started at 291 and 381 mV with the corresponding initial current density of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2, respectively, which demonstrated good stability during the whole i-t test. In addition, there are also some metal hydroxide heterostructure electrocatalysts showing good HER performance and stability at HCD. Zhang et al. [88] reported a TiO2/β-Ni(OH)2 hydrophily nanosheet arrays on NF (noted as Pt/TiO2/Ni(OH)2/NF), which is decorated by Pt. It is important that Pt/TiO2/Ni(OH)2/NF can reach HCD of 500, 1000 and 1500 mA cm–2 at low overpotentials of 107, 145 and 184 mV for HER, respectively. Fig. 11(f) showed that as time increases, the peak of TiO2 gradually strengthens, while Fig. 11(g) also showed that as time increases, the peak of Pt/TiO2/Ni(OH)2/NF becomes more pronounced, inferring that Pt and TiO2 are both located at the bottom of the vertical array. There are three main reasons for the excellent catalytic performance of HER under HCD conditions: (1) Pt and TiO2 located at the bottom of the vertical array ensure stability, (2) The synergistic effect between TiO2/Ni(OH)2 heterojunction interface and Pt are beneficial for the adsorption process of intermediates, (3) Surface hydrophilicity facilitates contact between active sites and electrolytes, while array structure facilitates bubble detachment. Wu et al. [84] used the solvothermal approach to prepare a heterostructure NiFe2O4 nanoparticles/NiFe LDH nanosheet array on NF (noted as NiFe2O4/NiFe LDH). NiFe2O4/NiFe LDH can drive HCD of 500 and 750 mA cm–2 for HER at a low overpotential of 297 and 314 mV in 1 mol L–1 KOH solution. Nanosheet structure can provide abundant active sites for HER processes and alleviate surface morphology changes caused by long-term operation under HCD conditions, resulting in good long-term catalytic stability. NiFe2O4 nanoparticles grow uniformly on NiFe LDH nanosheets, exposing a large number of active sites, promoting charge transfer and enhancing HER catalytic performance at HCD. 4.4 Metal sulfur/selenide electrocatalysts Metal sulfide electrocatalysts are low-cost electrocatalysts materials with great potential for industrial production. After several years of exploration, cheap transition metal sulfides (Fe, Ni, Mo, and Co, etc.) have shown excellent HER catalytic performance and long-term stability. Metal sulfide electrocatalysts usually have the following advantages, such as wide bandgap adjustment range, easier construction of heterojunctions by interlayer van der Waals forces, excellent stability, etc. However, metal sulfide electrocatalysts still have some issues that need to be addressed, including insufficient surface active site, highly affected by pH value, and complex synthesis process. In order to solve this series of problems, researchers have adopted strategies such as metal/non-metal doping, design of special multi-dimensional nanostructures, and modification of substrates to improve the performance of metal sulfide electrocatalysts. The commonly used synthesis methods for metal sulfide electrocatalysts include hydrothermal and calcination, chemical etch, vapor deposition, microwave irradiation, etc. Metal disulfides electrocatalysts have attracted great attention due to their excellent performance in the HER process, where metal disulfides electrocatalysts have a variety of crystal structures, and it is easier to optimize its performance through heteroatom doping than other kinds of metal sulfide electrocatalysts [103]. For metal disulfide, MoS2 is a typical excellent material for HER. Lu et al. [102] synthesized a Co-promoted 1T-MoS2 in hollow mesoporous carbon sphere (noted as 1T-Co-MoS2@HMCS), where a large number of pores and carbon structures of HMCS reveal a great quantity of active sites. Among these four different S sites, the Co-S edge site can better enhance the HER catalytic activity of 1T-Co-MoS2@HMCS (Fig. 11(h)) The HER activity of 1T-Co-MoS2@HMCS is better than Pt/C at HCD of 800 mA cm–2 in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH, the excellent HER catalytic performance of 1T-Co-MoS2@HMCS under HCD conditions can be attributed to the following factors: (1) Interlayer spacing of molybdenum disulfide has a positive effect on the formation of 1T-MoS2, (2) Mesoporous and carbonaceous structure of HMCS is very conducive to the exposure of active sites, accelerating the charge transfer and mass transfer rate, (3) Co-S edge sites formed after Co doping have excellent intrinsic activity. Our group [37] reported a P-doped 2H-MoS2 nanoflowers with rich S vacancy (noted as MoS2-P2), which has great potential for practical production and application. After calcination, the significant signal of Mo-S suspension bond of molybdenum disulfide is significantly weaker than that of MoS2-P2 (Fig. 11(i)), which confirms that phosphorus atom doping successfully introduces more sulfur vacancies into molybdenum disulfide. The sulfur vacancy is an important internal catalytic site, which can adjust the energy of the transition state to optimize the conductivity, and it can also enable the well coordinated inert base surface to be activated, thus enhancing the HCD catalytic performance of MoS2-P2. Nickel sulfide is also valued for its excellent performance. Researchers have synthesized some sulfide electrocatalysts containing both Ni and Mo, which exhibit excellent HER catalytic activity and long-term stability. Yu et al. [104] synthesized a N-doping Ni-Mo-based sulfide on NF (noted as N-NiMoS, which can work stably at HCD for long-term. At HCD of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2, the overpotentials of N-NiMoS are the smallest (250 and 322 mV). N-doping optimizes the hydrogen adsorption energy of the three sulfides and promotes the equilibrium of hydrogen adsorption and desorption, which is the key to the excellent HER catalytic performance of N-NiMoS. In addition, researchers found that metal selenides electrocatalysts also have the advantages of simple synthesis process, low cost, high catalytic activity and long-term stability similar to metal sulfides. The unique electronic structure of selenium makes the metal selenides have high metal abundance, which is conducive to reducing the R ct, thus accelerating the charge transfer rate on the electrocatalysts during the electrochemical water splitting process. Metal sulfide and metal selenide electrocatalysts have been able to surpass commercial Pt/C electrocatalysts in catalytic activity or stability. Metal selenides of Fe, Co and Ni are commonly used as ideal electrocatalysts for HER at HCD [105]. Gao et al. [110] synthesized Fe-doping NiSe nanorods and nanosheets layered arrays on NF (noted as Fe7.4%-NiSe) in one step, and the Fe3+ has the effect of enhancing synergy and improving electronic structure, which can accelerate the charge transfer rate. A special nanostructure of Fe7.4%-NiSe can also expose more active sites, effectively improving the HER activity at HCD. The special electrocatalyst integrating the S and Se in the metal sulfur-selenide electrocatalysts can also display the performance similar to the metal sulfide and metal selenide. Li et al. [106] synthesized a NiCo sulfur-selenide (noted as NiCoS x Se y ) nanosheet electrocatalysts. NiCoS x Se y exhibit excellent HER catalytic performance at HCD of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2, and the corresponding overpotentials of NiCoS x Se y are 256 and 345 mV, respectively. DOS calculation (Fig. 12(a) ) results show that the three interfaces CoS2-CoSe2, Ni3S2-Ni3Se2 and CoSe2-Ni3S2 all have metallic properties, and have higher DOS values near the Fermi level than single phase samples, which means a better conductivity, this is of great significance for enhancing the HER catalytic performance of electrocatalysts at HCD. 4.5 Metal nitrides electrocatalysts Metal nitride electrocatalysts have been considered as potential electrocatalysts by researchers for the formation of N can cause the d-band of non precious metal components to shrink, thus closer to the electronic structure of precious metals. Meanwhile, N atoms with smaller atomic radii are more likely to enter the original metal lattice, which allows the metal atoms to better maintain their dense packing structure. Many excellent metal nitride-based electrocatalysts have been modulated by using the strategies of heteroatom doping, design of heterostructure, design of multi-dimensional nanostructure and employing conductive substrate. The commonly used synthesis methods for metal nitride electrocatalysts include pulsed laser deposition, hydrothermal and calcination, reactive magnetron sputtering, etc. Metal nitrides change the metal structure by inserting nitrogen atoms into the gap between the original metal atoms. The gap between the metal atoms will expand with the insertion of nitrogen atoms, which effectively increases the length of the original metal d band, thus adjusting the density of state (DOS) and improving the performance of the electrocatalyst. Metal nitride electrocatalysts have the following advantages, such as thermal and chemical stability, high electronic conductivity, adjustable d-band, and excellent corrosion resistance. However, metal nitride electrocatalysts still have some issues that need to be addressed, including unstable in extreme acidic or alkaline environments, excessive N content reducing catalytic activity, complex synthesis process [111–113]. Zhou et al. [38] used hydrothermal and nitriding process to develop a N-doped porous Ni3Mo3N electrocatalyst (noted as NC/Ni3Mo3N/NF). At overpotential of 500 mV, current density of NC/Ni3Mo3N/NF is 668 mA cm–2 for HER, which is higher than that of Pt/C (379 mA cm–2). Moreover, at HCD of 1500 mA cm–2, the overpotential of NC/Ni3Mo3N/NF is as low as 954 mV. The long-term i-t test at HCD of 570 and 1100 mA cm–2 needs overpotentials of 500 and 900 mV for 50 h (Fig. 12(b)), respectively, and nearly without obvious current decay during the whole test process, which further proves the excellent stability of NC/Ni3Mo3N/NF. The presence of N optimizes the intermediate adsorption process on the surface of electrocatalysts. By doping transition metal atoms with excellent conductivity in metal nitrides, researchers have successfully synthesized transition metal nitride electrocatalysts with excellent HER catalytic performance. Jiao et al. [107] used the ammonia annealing process to synthesize a N-rich heterojunction of nitride (noted as Co-Mo5N6) with a heterogeneous interface composed of Co and Mo5N6, which has excellent mass transfer rate, conductivity, and specific surface area. The overpotentials of Co-Mo5N6 at HCD of 1000 mA cm–2 in 1 mol L–1 KOH and 1 mol L–1 buffer solution are 280 and 610 mV (Figs. 12(c) and 12(d)), respectively, lower than that of 20% Pt/C (650 and 765 mV). The strong interaction between the interfaces redistributes electrons, and Co doping prevents excessive oxidation of Mo, reduces the intermediate adsorption energy barrier, and thus effectively enhances the HER catalytic performance of Co-Mo5N6 under HCD conditions. Jin et al. [114] also synthesized Ni-doped W2N on NF (noted as Ni-W2N@NF), and doping of Ni can expose more electrochemical active sites. The overpotentiasl are only 317 and 345 mV for Ni-W2N@NF to achieve an industrial HCD of 2000 mA cm–2 in 1 mol L–1 KOH solution and 1500 mA cm–2 in an alkaline seawater solution, respectively. 4.6 Metal phosphide electrocatalysts Thanks to the large radius and triclinic structure of P atoms, metal phosphides are more likely to form unsaturated surface atoms with more coordination and isotropic crystal structures, making it easier for metal phosphides to achieve high catalytic activity. However, metal phosphide electrocatalysts still have some issues that need to be addressed, including prone to surface oxidation, highly affected by pH value, and complex synthesis process. In the selection of transition metal cations, Fe, Co and Ni with excellent conductivity are the most commonly used transition metal ions, and Nb and Mn phosphide also exhibit good catalytic performance as electrocatalysts. In recent years, researchers have successfully synthesized some metal phosphide electrocatalysts with high HER catalytic activity and long-term stability through heteroatom doping, designing multidimensional nanostructures and heterostructures, etc. The commonly used synthesis methods for metal phosphide electrocatalysts include hydrothermal, calcination, chemical vapor deposition, solid-state reduction and electrodeposition, etc. Metal phosphide electrocatalysts are type of electrocatalyst with great industrial production potential [115,116]. For metal phosphides, metal atom doping can play a role in providing active site and regulating electronic structure, which is conducive to the HER catalytic process. Ge et al. [108] prepared a Ni-Mn bimetallic doped FeP-based electrocatalyst (noted as Ni-Mn-FeP), and the 3D structure of FeP provides a great quantity of active sites, and the doped Ni and Mn accelerates the transfer of electrons. Near the Fermi level, compared with Ni-FeP, the TDOS of Ni-Mn-FeP is higher (Fig. 12(e)), which means that Mn doping effectively improves the conductivity and the HER catalytic activity of Ni-Mn-FeP under HCD conditions. The overpotential of Ni-Mn-FeP at 500 mA cm–2 is 243 mV. Fe-rich macroporous CoFeP (noted as CoFeP TPAs/Ni) is also based on FeP reported by Wei et al. [117]. Macroporous CoFeP TPAs/Ni exhibits excellent HER catalytic performance in alkaline environments at HCD, which is owing to the macroporous CoFeP TPAs/Ni with better mass transfer process. The overpotential of macroporous CoFeP TPAs/Ni at HCD of 900 mA cm–2 is only 263 mV. Macroporous CoFeP NPs/Ni initially had a crystalline structure while transformed into an amorphous structure after stability testing, which is beneficial for the HER catalytic process. For some metal phosphide electrocatalysts, F-doping can also significantly enhance their catalytic performance. Chai et al. [109] used the F-doping strategy to prepare an electrocatalyst with high catalytic activity at HCD of 3000 mA cm–2 (noted as F-Co2P/Fe2P/IF). The 3D structure of IF increases the active site of F-Co2P/Fe2P/IF, at the same time, it also makes F-Co2P/Fe2P/IF more difficult to dissolve and fall off, and enhances the catalytic activity and stability of F-Co2P/Fe2P/IF at HCD. Moreover, the F-doping causes a strong synergy between Co2P and Fe2P, and this makes it shows excellent HER catalytic activity. The overpotentials of F-Co2P/Fe2P/IF are 229.8, 260.5, 292.2, and 304.4 mV at HCD of 500, 1000, 2000, and 3000 mA cm–2, respectively (Fig. 12(f)). Moreover, the stability of F-Co2P/Fe2P/IF is tested in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH (Fig. 12(g)) solutions for 10 h at the HCD of 500, 1000, 2000 mA cm–2, respectively. The excellent HER performance can be attributed to three reasons, including the three-dimensional structure of IF provides a huge growth substrate for Co2P and Fe2P, F doping adjust the electronic structure of Co2P and Fe2P, the synergistic effect between Co2P and Fe2P enhances the activity of catalytic sites. By performing special pre-treatment on conductive substrates, the performance of electrocatalysts can also be optimized. Yu et al. [50] has developed a Co-Nb phosphide electrocatalyst on plasma modified carbon cloth (noted as CoP3-Nb2P/PCC) for HER. CoP3-Nb2P/PCC can reach HCD of 500, 600 and 1000 mA cm–2 at overpotentials of 317, 332 and 375 mV, respectively. In Figs. 13(a)–(c) , the peaks at 445 and 478 cm–1 are attributed to the Raman mode of CoP3, and it is evident from all three figures that the intensity of peaks at 445 and 478 cm–1 increases with increasing overpotential, indicating that CoP3 is the main active substance. According to the above results, it is speculated that the excellent HER activity at HCD of CoP3-Nb2P/PCC in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH solution is caused by the following factors: (1) The low electrochemical impedance of CoP3-Nb2P/PCC accelerates the diffusion of electrons in the HER process and improves the performance of HER.
