(2) PCC improves the conductivity of the electrocatalyst and the adhesive strength between material and CC fiber, and the defects on the surface of CC after plasma treatment are also beneficial for exposing the active sites of the electrocatalysts. 4.7 Other derived electrocatalysts In addition to the above-mentioned alloys, metal oxides, metal hydroxides, metal sulfides/selenides, metal nitrides and metal phosphides electrocatalysts, there are also some derived electrocatalysts formed by the combination of these six types of electrocatalysts. Combining different types of electrocatalysts can generate strong electronic coupling effects, protect active sites, and prevent metal valence state transitions from increasing or decreasing [120–122]. In addition, the unique synthesis strategy can also optimize the adsorption and desorption of intermediates during the reaction process by introducing other different chemical bonds, thus effectively improving the activity of the electrocatalyst at HCD. Song et al. [118] synthesized a heterostructured NiCoSx decorated carbonate hydroxide nanoflakes array cobalt on NF (noted as NiCoS x @CoCH NAs/NF), and the NiCoS x @CoCH NAs/NF displays the nano-layer structure and with the characteristic of superaerophobic, which can expose more active sites and weaken the corrosion loss caused by bubbles on the electrocatalyst surface. NiCoS x @CoCH NAs/NF can drive the HCD of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2 at the overpotentials of 338.0 and 438.5 mV, respectively. In the vicinity of Fermi level (Fig. 13(d)), NiCoS x @CoCH shows the highest occupation state among all samples. By comparing the PDOS values with NiCoS x and CoCH, it can be considered that the electronic structure of Co and Ni atoms can be adjusted to enhance the HER catalytic activity at HCD. Fan et al. [24] prepared a kind of miniature spherical electrocatalyst on NF, which is composed of Ni2P and WO2.83 (noted as Ni2P/WO2.83). The overpotential of Ni2P/WO2.83 is 254.5 mV at HCD of 1000 mA cm–2 for HER (Fig. 13(e)). Closely combined Ni2P and WO2.83 have excellent conductivity and hydrophilicity, and the microsphere structure also exposes a great quantity of active sites, which make Ni2P/WO2.83 display excellent HER catalytic activity. Ni2P/WO2.83. The water contact angle of Ni2P/WO2.83 is the lowest of 8.6° (Fig. 13(f)), demonstrating the excellent hydrophilicity of Ni2P/WO2.83, which means that the full use of active site is conducive to enhancing catalytic activity. It can be considered that the optimized Ni2P and WO2.83 have a synergistic effect in catalyzing the alkaline HER reaction, thereby greatly improving the inherent activity of the electrocatalysts at HCD. Our group [119] prepared PtNb-Nb2O5 cluster on CC (noted as PtNb-Nb2O5@CC) with strong metal support interaction, and Pt can maintain the valence state of Nb at HCD by combining with H*, which significantly enhances the stability of PtNb-Nb2O5@CC at HCD. And this cluster structure also provides more active sites, thus effectively enhancing HER catalytic activity of PtNb-Nb2O5@CC, which can reach HCD of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2 at overpotentials of 440 and 570 mV in seawater. As shown in Figs. 13(g) and 13(h), compared with Pt@CNT, the lower H–O–H bending vibration peak of PtNb-Nb2O5@CNT indicates that the introduction of Nb promotes water dissociation. As the reaction progresses, the O–H bond weakens, the red shift of peak of in-situ FTIR spectra of PtNb-Nb2O5@CNT from 1635.365 to 1634.37 cm–1 can prove this point. The adsorption of H* is mainly adsorbed on the Nb site of PtNb and then transferred to the Pt site for desorption. This improves the adsorption and desorption process of H* intermediates, which is very beneficial for enhancing HER catalytic performance at HCD. 5 Conclusions and outlook In summary, this paper first discusses the influence of HCD conditions on electrocatalyst and the design strategy of HCD electrocatalyst for HER process. Then we summarize the examples of different kinds of HCD electrocatalysts for HER published in recent years (Table 1 ). Although many excellent HCD electrocatalysts have been developed, there are still many problems to be solved. The industrial application of electrocatalysts has gradually been paid more attention, but there is still a long way to go to realize the industrial application of electrolytic water splitting at HCD. Therefore, the study of HCD electrocatalysts that can meet industrial production is still the focus of research, and there are still some challenges that need to be overcome to realize the industrial application as soon as possible (Fig. 14 ). 5.1 Exploiting new electrocatalysts and combining them with other fields Although some currently developed electrocatalysts have excellent HER catalytic activity at HCD, their stability is still not ideal. Especially at present, the method of testing the stability of electrocatalysts in the laboratory does not match the industrial production conditions. In actual industrial production, electrocatalysts need to be able to maintain stability for hundreds or even thousands of hours. Moreover, industrial production environments with unstable temperature, electrolyte density, and current density are far less stable than laboratory testing environments. Therefore, exploring new HCD electrocatalysts with high activity and good stability remains the core of research and exploration. According to current research progress, there are many electrocatalysts that focus on the selection of metal elements, such as non precious metals including Fe, Co, Ni, Cr or precious metals such as Ir, Pt, Ru, Pb, etc. However, there is relatively little research on electrocatalysts containing rare earth elements. The 15 rare earth elements in the sixth cycle starting from La have a special electron arrangement, which makes their atomic radii smaller than those in the fifth cycle. This special property may be beneficial for subjective regulation of electrocatalysts, thereby optimizing the catalytic performance catalysts. This may be the core of future research (Fig. 15(a) ). When designing electrocatalysts, it is necessary to consider many factors that can affect their performance, such as structure, morphology, surface chemistry, conductivity, etc. Correspondingly, various optimization strategies can also be adopted when designing electrocatalysts, which can simultaneously leverage the advantages of multiple strategies to better optimize HER catalytic performance At present, some studies have successfully optimized the HER performance of electrocatalysts using various strategies, but research on the optimization mechanism of electrocatalyst performance mostly focuses on a single element, lacking in-depth mechanism analysis of the interaction between multiple elements. Due to the increasing number of factors that can affect catalytic performance, the system combining multiple strategies is often more complex, which brings difficulties to the analysis work. In the future, more attention should be paid to the interaction between multiple strategies and the synergistic mechanism, and search for effective analytical methods to deepen the mechanism analysis of HER electrocatalysts (Fig. 15(b)). In terms of engineering design, systems such as heterogeneous interface engineering, heteroatom doping engineering, and defect engineering are relatively mature, but there is relatively little research on the mechanism of catalytic performance changes caused by lattice strain. Especially for layered electrocatalysts represented by LDH and hydroxyl oxides, their lattice spacing is easily affected by the intercalation of other atoms, and the effects of different atomic radii insertion are also different. So, in the future, research on lattice strain engineering should be strengthened (Fig. 15(c)). This article is categorized by elemental composition and provides examples to analyze and discuss the challenges, reaction mechanisms, design strategies, and engineering of HER electrocatalysts under HCD conditions. Although OER and ORR have different reaction mechanisms, how to improve catalytic activity and stability through engineering design methods under HCD conditions is relatively close. The questions and conclusions proposed in this article can also provide some guidance. Of course, not limited to the field of electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, thermal catalysis, enzyme catalysis, etc. all have some similar mechanisms and challenges to electrocatalysis, and this article can also provide ideas for them. According to the analysis of the factors that affect the performance of electrocatalysts and the design of electrocatalyst strategies in the previous text, the electron transfer process is an important factor. Currently, many studies on electron transfer processes focus on adjusting local electron cloud density and optimizing electron transfer pathways. This year, some scholars have proposed non-metallic electron bridges to explain the specific optimization process and reasons for electron transfer pathways, which is helpful for studying the mechanism of electrocatalyst reaction and performance optimization under HCD conditions. In the future, research on non-metallic electronic bridges should also be strengthened (Fig. 15(d)). 5.2 Performance testing for simulating industrial environments Although some currently developed electrocatalysts have excellent HER catalytic activity at HCD, their stability is still not ideal. Especially at present, the method of testing the stability of electrocatalysts in the laboratory does not match the industrial production conditions. In actual industrial production, electrocatalysts need to be able to maintain stability for hundreds or even thousands of hours. Moreover, industrial production environments with unstable temperature, electrolyte density, and current density are far less stable than laboratory testing environments. Therefore, exploring new HCD electrocatalysts with high activity and good stability remains the core of research and exploration. From the perspectives of materials, performance, efficiency, and cost, anion exchange membrane (AEM) and proton exchange membrane (PEM) are very suitable for simulating industrial hydrogen production processes in laboratory environments (Fig. 16 ). The main structure of AEM electrolysis for hydrogen production technology consists of an anion exchange membrane and two transition metal catalytic electrodes. It generally uses pure water or low concentration alkaline solutions as electrolytes, and uses inexpensive non precious metal catalysts and hydrocarbon membranes. Therefore, the AEM process has the advantages of low cost, fast start and stop, and low energy consumption, which combines the ease of operation when coupled with renewable energy. The PEM electrolysis cell uses pure water as the reactant, which can be adapted to acidic and alkaline environments. The low hydrogen permeation rate of PEM electrolyte results in high purity of the generated hydrogen, and subsequent treatment only requires the removal of water vapor. Not only that, PEM electrolysis cells also have the characteristics of small volume, simple process, and high safety. According to the principle of electrolytic cells and the purpose of industrial applications, the design of HER electrocatalysts for HCD should ultimately return to the goal of electrocatalytic water splitting. When applying HER electrocatalysts to industrial production, the OER reaction occurring on the anode can also have an impact on the water electrolysis process. Due to the need for more electrons during the reaction process, OER can have a greater impact on the speed of the entire electrocatalytic water splitting process than HER. However, the change in pH value has a greater impact on the OER, and the acidic environment favorable for the HER is extremely unfavorable for the OER process. Considering this, in the future, more attention should be paid to researching HER electrocatalysts that can be adapted to alkaline environments. This is also why we chose more research in alkaline electrolytes when giving examples. 6.3 Effect of HCD on electrochemical interface The electrochemical environment on the surface of electrocatalysts may undergo significant changes under HCD conditions, but there is currently little discussion on this issue in current research. Due to the large number of bubbles generated on the surface of electrocatalysts under HCD conditions, which can affect radiation and hinder observation and analysis, a method is needed to solve this problem. The commonly used in-situ characterization methods include (1) in-situ EIS: distinguish the resistance of electron transfer, ion transfer, and polarization generated during electrochemical reactions through different frequency changes. This is the easiest in-situ test to achieve, which can be combined with Bode diagrams to analyze the changes in electrocatalysts with voltage, but cannot analyze the detailed changes in crystal phase, structure, and material equality. (2) In-situ Raman spectroscopy: analyze the evolution process and electrochemical reaction mechanism of materials on electrocatalysts. In-situ Raman spectroscopy can analyze the phase transition, chemical bond changes, and electron transfer that occur during the reaction process based on the position and intensity changes of spectral characteristic peaks. (3) In-situ AFM: analyze the surface morphology, structure, chain conformation, and other aspects of the sample. The main purpose of AFM is to observe the length, thickness, and other scales of the microstructure of electrocatalysts. In-situ AFM can monitor the scale changes of the surface morphology and structure of electrocatalysts. (4) Operando infrared spectroscopy: analyze the surface structure and surface adsorption species of solid powder samples. Infrared spectroscopy is similar to Raman spectroscopy, but more suitable for monitoring changes in chemical bonds. (5) In-situ XRD: analyze the crystal type, crystal parameters, crystal defects of materials, and quantitatively analyze the relative content of different structural phases. (6) In-situ UV: analyze the electronic structure and band structure of materials. Testing the solution after long-term stability testing can effectively monitor changes in metal dissolution and non-metallic components. (7) In-situ XPS: can analyze the changes in the valence state and content of elements through the displacement and area changes of characteristic peaks, and is a cheap and efficient in-situ characterization method. The use of in-situ characterization for HCD is to monitor the changes in electrocatalysts with current density, which is of great help in analyzing the changes and mechanisms of electrocatalysts during the HER process under HCD conditions. (8) In-situ synchrotron radiation: in-situ synchrotron radiation is an advanced characterization method applied in the study of electrocatalysts in recent years. It can be used to study the valence state changes, electron migration, bond length changes, atomic coordination, orbital transitions, and other processes of electrocatalysts during the reaction process. It is currently a very effective and intuitive means of studying electron transfer in the reaction process. 6.4 Recycling and reuse One purpose of studying HCD electrocatalysts for water splitting is to develop clean energy to address environmental and resource issues. However, some HCD electrocatalysts currently being studied face the problem of difficult to recycle, which can lead to resource waste. There are also some toxic and harmful substances in the materials used for synthesizing electrocatalysts, and waste electrocatalysts that cannot be recovered can become new pollutants. Many current strategies for synthesizing HCD electrocatalysts require the use of toxic, harmful, and even high-risk chemicals. The chemical waste, exhaust gas, or wastewater generated during the synthesis process not only have adverse effects on the environment, but also pose a threat to human health. In future research, attention should not only be paid to the selection and recycling of experimental drugs, but also to the development of green synthesis strategies (etching, microwave, Joule heating, etc.). Therefore, when researching high-performance HCD electrocatalysts that can be used in industrial production, it is also necessary to consider the recovery of waste electrocatalysts. Subsequently, from 2008 to 2010, he pursued postdoctoral research at the State Key Laboratory of Crystal Materials, Shandong University. He is currently a professor of chemistry at Qingdao University of Science and Technology. His research interests mainly focus on the design and synthesis of functional organic-inorganic hybrids and porous MOFs materials, as well as their applications in photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, lithium-ion battery, etc. Xiaobin Liu received his PhD from University of Science and Technology Beijing in 2020. He is currently an associate professor at Qingdao University of Science and Technology. His research interests focus on the synthesis of nanomaterials and their application in the field of electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Zhenyu Xiao was awarded a PhD in China University of Petroleum (East China) in 2017 under the supervision of Prof. Daofeng Sun. He is currently an associate professor at Qingdao University of Science and Technology. His research interests mainly focus on metal-organic frame materials, nanomaterials, supercapacitor, and electrocatalysis.

coredata.dc:description: The electrolysis of water powered by renewable energy sources offers a promising method of “green hydrogen” production, which is considered to be at the heart of future carbon-neutral energy systems. In the past decades, researchers have reported a number of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalysts with activity comparable to that of commercial Pt/C, but most of them are tested within a small current density range, typically no more than 500 mA cm–2. To realize the industrial application of hydrogen production from water electrolysis, it is essential to develop high-efficiency HER electrocatalysts at high current density (HCD ≥ 500 mA cm–2). Nevertheless, it remains challenging and significant to rational design HCD electrocatalysts for HER. In this paper, the design strategy of HCD electrocatalysts is discussed, and some HCD electrocatalysts for HER are reviewed in seven categories (alloy, metal oxide, metal hydroxide, metal sulfide/selenide, metal nitride, metal phosphide and other derived electrocatalysts). At the end of this article, we also propose some viewpoints and prospects for the future development and research directions of HCD electrocatalysts for HER.
